htmlEmbed:
Facebook Gave Nebraska Cops A Teen’s DMs. They Used Them To Prosecute Her For Having An Abortion.Emily Baker-White7/8/2022

A Nebraska teenager is facing criminal charges alleging she aborted a fetus in violation of state law, after authorities obtained her Facebook messages using a search warrant.

Nebraska Cops Supoenaed A Teen, Facebook, abortion, nebraska, InnovationRead

class="embed-base image-embed embed-3" role="presentation"> 
 <div style="padding-top: 66.53%; position: relative;" class="image-embed__placeholder"> <progressive-image src="https://specials-images.forbesimg.com/imageserve/62f2a1641db96325341d9c76/A-woman-using-mobile-phone-at-night/1960x0.jpg?fit=scale" alt="A woman using mobile phone at night" class="" data-height="1537" data-width="2306"></progressive-image> 
 </div> 
 <figcaption> 
  <p class="color-body light-text">This marks one of the first instances of a person’s Facebook activity being used to incriminate her in a state where abortion access is restricted.</p><small class="color-body light-text">getty</small> 
 </figcaption> 
</figure>
<p>A Nebraska teenager is facing criminal charges alleging she aborted a fetus in violation of state law, after authorities obtained her Facebook messages using a search warrant. Seventeen-year-old Celeste Burgess, who is being tried as an adult along with her mother Jessica Burgess, is awaiting trial in Madison County District Court on charges that they broke a Nebraska law banning abortions after 20 weeks.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_1"></div>
<div class="article_paragraph_2"></div>
<fbs-ad position="top" progressive="" ad-id="article-0-top"></fbs-ad>
<p>This marks one of the first instances of a person’s Facebook activity being used to incriminate her in a state where abortion access is restricted — a scenario that has remained largely hypothetical in the weeks following the US Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Nebraska currently outlaws abortions beyond 20 weeks. On Monday, Republican lawmakers in the state <a href="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/nebraska-republicans-lack-votes-pass-12-week-abortion-ban-2022-08-08/" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.reuters.com/world/us/nebraska-republicans-lack-votes-pass-12-week-abortion-ban-2022-08-08/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.reuters.com/world/us/nebraska-republicans-lack-votes-pass-12-week-abortion-ban-2022-08-08/" aria-label="failed to secure enough votes">failed to secure enough votes</a> to decrease that window to 12 weeks.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_2"></div>
<p>Celeste and her mother were charged in July with allegedly removing, concealing or abandoning a dead human body and concealing the death of another person after the Norfolk Police Department received a tip claiming Celeste had miscarried in April at 23 weeks of pregnancy and secretly buried the fetus with her mother's help. The case was previously reported by several local media outlets, including the <a href="https://norfolkdailynews.com/select/news/prosecutor-alleges-woman-bought-pills-for-girl-that-induced-unborn-babys-death/article_ed0464de-f6ef-11ec-b9e4-039128dc5a38.html" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://norfolkdailynews.com/select/news/prosecutor-alleges-woman-bought-pills-for-girl-that-induced-unborn-babys-death/article_ed0464de-f6ef-11ec-b9e4-039128dc5a38.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://norfolkdailynews.com/select/news/prosecutor-alleges-woman-bought-pills-for-girl-that-induced-unborn-babys-death/article_ed0464de-f6ef-11ec-b9e4-039128dc5a38.html" aria-label="Norfolk Daily News">Norfolk Daily News</a> and the <a href="https://journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/nebraska/norfolk-mother-and-daughter-accused-of-illegal-abortion-burning-and-burying-body/article_ff99fd49-a710-5ec3-8d51-5aced3001c71.html" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/nebraska/norfolk-mother-and-daughter-accused-of-illegal-abortion-burning-and-burying-body/article_ff99fd49-a710-5ec3-8d51-5aced3001c71.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://journalstar.com/news/state-and-regional/nebraska/norfolk-mother-and-daughter-accused-of-illegal-abortion-burning-and-burying-body/article_ff99fd49-a710-5ec3-8d51-5aced3001c71.html" aria-label="Lincoln Journal Star">Lincoln Journal Star</a>. </p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_3"></div>
<p>While Celeste told police that she had suffered a miscarriage, they continued to investigate, serving Facebook with a search warrant to access Celeste and Jessica’s Facebook accounts. They subsequently found messages between the mother and daughter allegedly detailing how Celeste had undergone a self-managed abortion with Jessica’s help. There are four states that ban abortion at 24 weeks, and more than a dozen that broadly ban it at the start of fetal viability.</p>
<div class="halfway_hardwall_4"></div>
<p>After this story's publication, Meta spokesperson Andy Stone said in a statement on Twitter that "Nothing in the valid warrants we received from local law enforcement in early June, prior to the Supreme Court decision, mentioned abortion. The warrants concerned charges related to a criminal investigation and court documents indicate that police at the time were investigating the case of a stillborn baby who was burned and buried, not a decision to have an abortion."Stone added that Meta was prohibited from sharing information about the search warrant by non-disclosure orders which have since been lifted.</p>
<div class="article_paragraph_7"></div>
<p>A month before Celeste was charged, Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Facebook parent Meta, was asked by employees how the company will protect those seeking abortions. Zuckerberg replied that efforts to expand encryption across the platform will “keep people safe,” <a href="https://www.cyberscoop.com/mark-zuckerberg-meta-facebook-abortion-roe-wade-privacy/" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.cyberscoop.com/mark-zuckerberg-meta-facebook-abortion-roe-wade-privacy/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.cyberscoop.com/mark-zuckerberg-meta-facebook-abortion-roe-wade-privacy/" aria-label="CyberScoop reported"><em data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.cyberscoop.com/mark-zuckerberg-meta-facebook-abortion-roe-wade-privacy/">CyberScoop </em>reported</a>. In May, Meta’s VP of HR, Janelle Gale, told employees they were not allowed to discuss abortion at work, <a href="https://www.theverge.com/2022/5/19/23131714/meta-ban-abortion-discussion-at-work-facebook-workplace-roe-v-wade" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.theverge.com/2022/5/19/23131714/meta-ban-abortion-discussion-at-work-facebook-workplace-roe-v-wade" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.theverge.com/2022/5/19/23131714/meta-ban-abortion-discussion-at-work-facebook-workplace-roe-v-wade" aria-label="according to the Verge">according to the <em data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.theverge.com/2022/5/19/23131714/meta-ban-abortion-discussion-at-work-facebook-workplace-roe-v-wade">Verge</em></a>. The company <a href="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/abortion-travel-companies-paying-benefits-amazon-starbucks-target/" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.cbsnews.com/news/abortion-travel-companies-paying-benefits-amazon-starbucks-target/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.cbsnews.com/news/abortion-travel-companies-paying-benefits-amazon-starbucks-target/" aria-label="later announced">later announced</a> that it will reimburse employees who find they must travel to a different state to seek an abortion.</p>
<p>Still, Meta has <a href="https://www.technologyreview.com/2022/06/28/1055044/big-tech-data-privacy-supreme-court-dobbs-abortion/" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.technologyreview.com/2022/06/28/1055044/big-tech-data-privacy-supreme-court-dobbs-abortion/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.technologyreview.com/2022/06/28/1055044/big-tech-data-privacy-supreme-court-dobbs-abortion/" aria-label="remained largely silent">remained largely silent</a> on how it will moderate abortion content in general. However, users recently noticed that <a href="https://www.npr.org/2022/06/28/1108107718/instagram-and-facebook-begin-removing-posts-offering-abortion-pills" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.npr.org/2022/06/28/1108107718/instagram-and-facebook-begin-removing-posts-offering-abortion-pills" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.npr.org/2022/06/28/1108107718/instagram-and-facebook-begin-removing-posts-offering-abortion-pills" aria-label="Instagram and Facebook posts">Instagram and Facebook posts</a> about acquiring abortion pills such as mifepristone were being systematically removed. At the same time, Meta continued to earn revenue from anti-abortion advertisements containing dangerous misinformation,<em> </em><a href="https://www.mediamatters.org/facebook/facebook-has-earned-tens-thousands-dollars-running-ads-misinformation-about-abortion-pills" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.mediamatters.org/facebook/facebook-has-earned-tens-thousands-dollars-running-ads-misinformation-about-abortion-pills" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.mediamatters.org/facebook/facebook-has-earned-tens-thousands-dollars-running-ads-misinformation-about-abortion-pills" aria-label="Media Matters found"><em data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.mediamatters.org/facebook/facebook-has-earned-tens-thousands-dollars-running-ads-misinformation-about-abortion-pills">Media Matters</em> found</a>. An <a href="https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/06/15/facebook-and-anti-abortion-clinics-are-collecting-highly-sensitive-info-on-would-be-patients" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/06/15/facebook-and-anti-abortion-clinics-are-collecting-highly-sensitive-info-on-would-be-patients" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/06/15/facebook-and-anti-abortion-clinics-are-collecting-highly-sensitive-info-on-would-be-patients" aria-label="investigation by the Markup">investigation by the <em data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://themarkup.org/pixel-hunt/2022/06/15/facebook-and-anti-abortion-clinics-are-collecting-highly-sensitive-info-on-would-be-patients">Markup</em></a> discovered that Facebook was collecting data from users interacting with abortion services websites, and subequently made that information available to anti-abortion groups. </p>
<fbs-ad position="topx" progressive="" ad-id="article-0-topx-1"></fbs-ad>
<p>In response to pressure from employees, <a href="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/01/technology/google-abortion-location-data.html" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/01/technology/google-abortion-location-data.html" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.nytimes.com/2022/07/01/technology/google-abortion-location-data.html" aria-label="Google announced">Google announced</a> that it would delete location data of users who had used the platform to look up abortion services.</p>
<p>All of the largest tech giants have been pressed on whether, and to what extent, they may cooperate in investigations that seek to punish women for seeking an abortion. In June, Meta spokesperson Andy Stone <a href="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/06/29/google-facebook-abortion-data/" target="_blank" class="color-link" title="https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/06/29/google-facebook-abortion-data/" rel="nofollow noopener noreferrer" data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/06/29/google-facebook-abortion-data/" aria-label="told the Washington Post">told the <em data-ga-track="ExternalLink:https://www.washingtonpost.com/technology/2022/06/29/google-facebook-abortion-data/">Washington Post</em></a> that the company “carefully scrutinize[s] all government requests for user information and often push[es] back, including in court.”</p>
<p>A District Attorney assigned to the case declined to comment. An attorney for Celeste Burgess did not immediately respond to a request for comment. </p>
<p><em>Update: This story has been updated to note that the Facebook messages were obtained via search warrant.</em></p>

readabilityObject.title: Facebook Gave Nebraska Cops A Teen’s DMs. They Used Them To Prosecute Her For Having An Abortion.
readabilityObject.content:
A Nebraska teenager is facing criminal charges alleging she aborted a fetus in violation of state law, after authorities obtained her Facebook messages using a search warrant. Seventeen-year-old Celeste Burgess, who is being tried as an adult along with her mother Jessica Burgess, is awaiting trial in Madison County District Court on charges that they broke a Nebraska law banning abortions after 20 weeks.

This marks one of the first instances of a person’s Facebook activity being used to incriminate her in a state where abortion access is restricted — a scenario that has remained largely hypothetical in the weeks following the US Supreme Court’s decision to overturn Roe v. Wade. Nebraska currently outlaws abortions beyond 20 weeks. On Monday, Republican lawmakers in the state failed to secure enough votes to decrease that window to 12 weeks.

Celeste and her mother were charged in July with allegedly removing, concealing or abandoning a dead human body and concealing the death of another person after the Norfolk Police Department received a tip claiming Celeste had miscarried in April at 23 weeks of pregnancy and secretly buried the fetus with her mother's help. The case was previously reported by several local media outlets, including the Norfolk Daily News and the Lincoln Journal Star.

While Celeste told police that she had suffered a miscarriage, they continued to investigate, serving Facebook with a search warrant to access Celeste and Jessica’s Facebook accounts. They subsequently found messages between the mother and daughter allegedly detailing how Celeste had undergone a self-managed abortion with Jessica’s help. There are four states that ban abortion at 24 weeks, and more than a dozen that broadly ban it at the start of fetal viability.

After this story's publication, Meta spokesperson Andy Stone said in a statement on Twitter that "Nothing in the valid warrants we received from local law enforcement in early June, prior to the Supreme Court decision, mentioned abortion. The warrants concerned charges related to a criminal investigation and court documents indicate that police at the time were investigating the case of a stillborn baby who was burned and buried, not a decision to have an abortion."Stone added that Meta was prohibited from sharing information about the search warrant by non-disclosure orders which have since been lifted.

A month before Celeste was charged, Mark Zuckerberg, CEO of Facebook parent Meta, was asked by employees how the company will protect those seeking abortions. Zuckerberg replied that efforts to expand encryption across the platform will “keep people safe,” CyberScoop reported. In May, Meta’s VP of HR, Janelle Gale, told employees they were not allowed to discuss abortion at work, according to the Verge. The company later announced that it will reimburse employees who find they must travel to a different state to seek an abortion.

Still, Meta has remained largely silent on how it will moderate abortion content in general. However, users recently noticed that Instagram and Facebook posts about acquiring abortion pills such as mifepristone were being systematically removed. At the same time, Meta continued to earn revenue from anti-abortion advertisements containing dangerous misinformation, Media Matters found. An investigation by the Markup discovered that Facebook was collecting data from users interacting with abortion services websites, and subequently made that information available to anti-abortion groups.

In response to pressure from employees, Google announced that it would delete location data of users who had used the platform to look up abortion services.

All of the largest tech giants have been pressed on whether, and to what extent, they may cooperate in investigations that seek to punish women for seeking an abortion. In June, Meta spokesperson Andy Stone told the Washington Post that the company “carefully scrutinize[s] all government requests for user information and often push[es] back, including in court.”

A District Attorney assigned to the case declined to comment. An attorney for Celeste Burgess did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Update: This story has been updated to note that the Facebook messages were obtained via search warrant.
